elements.content: Using a pyridine-based bi-triazole ligand 2,6-di-(1,2,4-triazole-4-yl)pyridine (L), we have synthesized four novel Zn(II)/Cd(II) coordination polymers, namely, {[Zn3L4(NCS)6]·2CH3OH·H2O} n (1), [CdL2(NCS)2] n (2), [CdL2(NO3)2] n (3), and {[CdL(μ-ox)(H2O)]·2H2O} n (4) (ox = oxalate anion). 1 is the first triazole−zinc(II) compound simultaneously comprising four- and six-coordinate zinc(II) centers. Weak C−H···N and C−H···S interactions assembled 1D chains of 1 into a 3D supramolecular network, in which 1D hydrophilic channels encapsulating guest water and methanol molecules can be found. 2 contains a 1D double-stranded chain using CdL2(NCS)2 as repeating unit. 3 is a 2D polymer with chiral group P212121, indicating achiral ligand L and metal centers can be used as building blocks to construct chiral crystals. For 4, Cd(II) centers are linked via a bis(bidentate) oxalate anion to form 1D zigzag chains; furthermore, lattice water molecules act as hydrogen-bonding nodes to extend 4 into a 2D layer structure through strong O···O hydrogen synthons. Intensive solid-state fluorescence spectra of 1−4 have been determined.
elements.clean_text: Using a pyridine-based bi-triazole ligand 2,6-di-(1,2,4-triazole-4-yl)pyridine (L), we have synthesized four novel Zn(II)/Cd(II) coordination polymers, namely, {[Zn3L4(NCS)6]⋅2CH3OH⋅H2O} n  (1), [CdL2(NCS)2] n  (2), [CdL2(NO3)2] n  (3), and {[CdL(μ-ox)(H2O)]⋅2H2O} n  (4) (ox = oxalate anion). 1 is the first triazole-zinc(II) compound simultaneously comprising four- and six-coordinate zinc(II) centers. Weak C-H⋅⋅⋅N and C-H⋅⋅⋅S interactions assembled 1D chains of 1 into a 3D supramolecular network, in which 1D hydrophilic channels encapsulating guest water and methanol molecules can be found. 2 contains a 1D double-stranded chain using CdL2(NCS)2 as repeating unit. 3 is a 2D polymer with chiral group P212121, indicating achiral ligand L and metal centers can be used as building blocks to construct chiral crystals. For 4, Cd(II) centers are linked via a bis(bidentate) oxalate anion to form 1D zigzag chains; furthermore, lattice water molecules act as hydrogen-bonding nodes to extend 4 into a 2D layer structure through strong O⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen synthons. Intensive solid-state fluorescence spectra of 1-4 have been determined.

elements.content: Four novel coordination polymers were isolated by the reaction of a luminescent ligand, 2,6-di-(1,2,4-triazole-4-yl)pyridine, and metal centers. Anions and metal centers could tune the supramolecular self-assembly to form different structural motifs. 1 is the first triazole−zinc(II) compound simultaneously comprising four- and six-coordinate zinc(II) centers. Compound 3 contains a 2D helical layer to give chiral space group P212121.
elements.clean_text: Four novel coordination polymers were isolated by the reaction of a luminescent ligand, 2,6-di-(1,2,4-triazole-4-yl)pyridine, and metal centers. Anions and metal centers could tune the supramolecular self-assembly to form different structural motifs. 1 is the first triazole-zinc(II) compound simultaneously comprising four- and six-coordinate zinc(II) centers. Compound 3 contains a 2D helical layer to give chiral space group P212121.

elements.content: In recent years, coordination polymers have achieved considerable progress in the field of supramolecular chemistry and crystal engineering, because of their intriguing structural motifs and functional properties, such as molecular adsorption, magnetism, and luminescence. In the crystal engineering of coordination frameworks, judicious selection of ligands as basic building blocks is important because deliberately structural changes about organic building blocks such as length, flexibility, and symmetry can dramatically change ultimate structural motifs of these coordination frameworks. Therefore, many new flexible or rigid ligands have been explored and assembled into metal−organic frameworks via coordination bonds or weak supramolecular interactions such as hydrogen bonds, π−π stacking, and host−guest ionic interactions, etc. 1,2,4-Triazole and its derivatives are very interesting ligands because they combine the coordination geometry of both pyrazoles and imidazoles with regard to the arrangement of their three heteroatoms. A large number of mononuclear, oligonuclear, and polynuclear metal coordination compounds with 1,2,4-triazole derivatives have been prepared and characterized because of their interesting magnetic properties and novel topologies. Previously, we reported a series of triazolate−metal(II) coordination polymers with different coordination modes tuned via different triazole ligands and anions. And the luminescence properties of the ligands and selective coordination polymers in the solid state and in water solution were explored. Unlike other 1,2,4-triazole derivatives, 2,6-di-(1,2,4-triazole-4-yl)pyridine (L) is a rigid angular multifunctional ligand containing one pyridine and two triazole groups, which are both strong coordination donors to metal centers. Therefore, L can be expected to construct many high-dimensional and highly connected coordination frameworks in which L can also adopt many versatile coordination modes. On the other hand, two triazole groups on the pyridine rings of L has a specific bent angles. The resulting frameworks based on L must meet the specific angles because of the rigidity of pyridine ring moieties. The ligand L as building blocks is more predictable in the crystal engineering of coordination frameworks than those using flexible ligands because the specific geometry of L must be satisfied. Using this bi-triazole ligand, we herein report a series of novel coordination polymers {[Zn3L4(NCS)6]·2CH3OH·H2O} n (1), [CdL2(NCS)2] n (2), [CdL2(NO3)2] n (3), and {[CdL(μ-ox)(H2O)]·2H2O} n (4) (ox = oxalate anion). The compounds 1, 2, and 4 are 1D coordination chains with different structural motifs, whereas 3 is a 2D polymer with chiral group P212121 constructed by achiral ligand L. Compared with the organic ligand L, all compounds exhibit luminescence properties with stronger intensities.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, coordination polymers have achieved considerable progress in the field of supramolecular chemistry and crystal engineering, because of their intriguing structural motifs and functional properties, such as molecular adsorption, magnetism, and luminescence. In the crystal engineering of coordination frameworks, judicious selection of ligands as basic building blocks is important because deliberately structural changes about organic building blocks such as length, flexibility, and symmetry can dramatically change ultimate structural motifs of these coordination frameworks. Therefore, many new flexible or rigid ligands have been explored and assembled into metal-organic frameworks via coordination bonds or weak supramolecular interactions such as hydrogen bonds, π-π stacking, and host-guest ionic interactions, etc. 1,2,4-Triazole and its derivatives are very interesting ligands because they combine the coordination geometry of both pyrazoles and imidazoles with regard to the arrangement of their three heteroatoms. A large number of mononuclear, oligonuclear, and polynuclear metal coordination compounds with 1,2,4-triazole derivatives have been prepared and characterized because of their interesting magnetic properties and novel topologies. Previously, we reported a series of triazolate-metal(II) coordination polymers with different coordination modes tuned via different triazole ligands and anions. And the luminescence properties of the ligands and selective coordination polymers in the solid state and in water solution were explored. Unlike other 1,2,4-triazole derivatives, 2,6-di-(1,2,4-triazole-4-yl)pyridine (L) is a rigid angular multifunctional ligand containing one pyridine and two triazole groups, which are both strong coordination donors to metal centers. Therefore, L can be expected to construct many high-dimensional and highly connected coordination frameworks in which L can also adopt many versatile coordination modes. On the other hand, two triazole groups on the pyridine rings of L has a specific bent angles. The resulting frameworks based on L must meet the specific angles because of the rigidity of pyridine ring moieties. The ligand L as building blocks is more predictable in the crystal engineering of coordination frameworks than those using flexible ligands because the specific geometry of L must be satisfied. Using this bi-triazole ligand, we herein report a series of novel coordination polymers {[Zn3L4(NCS)6]⋅2CH3OH⋅H2O} n  (1), [CdL2(NCS)2] n  (2), [CdL2(NO3)2] n  (3), and {[CdL(μ-ox)(H2O)]⋅2H2O} n  (4) (ox = oxalate anion). The compounds 1, 2, and 4 are 1D coordination chains with different structural motifs, whereas 3 is a 2D polymer with chiral group P212121 constructed by achiral ligand L. Compared with the organic ligand L, all compounds exhibit luminescence properties with stronger intensities.

elements.content: General Methods. The triazole ligand Lwas synthesized according to the literature method. All other reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. Elemental analyses of carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen were carried out with a Perkin-Elmer analyzer model 240. The infrared spectra on KBr pellets were obtained on a Bruker Vector 22 FT-IR instrument in the 400−4000 cm-1 region. The photoluminescence spectra were measured by a MPF-4 fluorescence spectrophotometer with a xenon arc lamp as the light source.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 General Methods. The triazole ligand Lwas synthesized according to the literature method. All other reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. Elemental analyses of carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen were carried out with a Perkin-Elmer analyzer model 240. The infrared spectra on KBr pellets were obtained on a Bruker Vector 22 FT-IR instrument in the 400-4000 cm-1 region. The photoluminescence spectra were measured by a MPF-4 fluorescence spectrophotometer with a xenon arc lamp as the light source.

elements.content: Synthesis of {[Zn 3 L 4 (NCS) 6 ]·2CH 3 OH·H 2 O} n (1). A solution of L (10.8 mg, 0.05 mmol) in a 1:1 mixture of methanol and H2O (20 mL) was added to a solution of Zn(NCS)2 (9.0 mg, 0.05 mmol) in H2O (10 mL). The resulting solution was refluxed with stirring for ca. 3 h and then filtrated to stand for several days at room temperature. Colorless crystals were obtained in 31% yield based on Zn(II) salts. Anal. Calcd. for C22H19N17O1.5S3Zn1.5 (1):  C, 35.72; H, 2.59; N, 32.19. Found:  C, 35.85; H, 2.65; N, 32.45. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3429 (s), 3370 (m), 2075 (s), 1640 (s), 1523 (m), 1412 (s), 1254 (m), 1176 (m), 1020 (m), 870 (m), 762 (w), 617 (w), 529 (w).

elements.content: X-ray Crystallography. Structure measurements of complexes 1−4 were performed on a computer controlled Bruker SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo−Kα radiation with radiation wavelength 0.71073 Å using the ω-scan technique. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL- 97 programs. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. The organic hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically; the hydrogen atoms of the water molecules were located from difference maps and refined with isotropic temperature factors. Analytical expressions of neutral-atom scattering factors were employed, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated. The crystallographic data and selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Tables and , respectively. CCDC reference numbers 624873 (1), 624872 (2), 624874 (3), and 631973 (4) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.can.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html (or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB21EZ, UK; Fax (+44) 1223−336033; or deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).
elements.clean_text: X-ray Crystallography. Structure measurements of complexes 1-4 were performed on a computer controlled Bruker SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation with radiation wavelength 0.71073 Å using the ω-scan technique. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL- 97 programs. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. The organic hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically; the hydrogen atoms of the water molecules were located from difference maps and refined with isotropic temperature factors. Analytical expressions of neutral-atom scattering factors were employed, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated. The crystallographic data and selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Tables  and , respectively. CCDC reference numbers 624873 (1), 624872 (2), 624874 (3), and 631973 (4) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.can.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html (or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB21EZ, UK; Fax (+44) 1223-336033; or deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

elements.content: Complexes 1−4 are air-stable and can retain their structural integrity at room temperature for a considerable length of time. Notably, the reflux reaction conditions are essential for preparing the final compounds of 1−4. Compounds 1−4 have been prepared in H2O/ethanol mixed-solvent systems with different organic anion co-ligands (NCS-, NO3 -, ox2-). Though the ligand L contains seven N atoms, only four N atoms of triazole rings can participate in coordination and the steric effect prevents other N atoms of L from metal coordination. Because both N1 and N2 in the triazole ring can coordinate with metal ions, there are three bidentate coordination modes, as shown in Scheme . 1 contains modes a and b, whereas 2 and 3 have only mode b and c, respectively. The different coordination modes draw the self-assembly of coordination polymers to form 1D or 2D metal−organic frameworks. It is noted that the angles between benzene and triazole rings are flexible. The various coordination modes together with the flexible dihedral angles make the fact that we could not succeed to anticipate the self-assembly results of L and metal ions. In compounds 1−3, L adopts bidentate bridging mode, whereas thiocyanate or nitrate ligands adopt a monodentate N-coordination mode; in 4, L adopts only the terminal monodentate mode, which may be ascribed to the different coordination abilities for ligand and anion co-ligands. The coordination ability of L is stronger than that of thiocyanate or nitrate anions but weaker than that of oxalate anion ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Complexes 1-4 are air-stable and can retain their structural integrity at room temperature for a considerable length of time. Notably, the reflux reaction conditions are essential for preparing the final compounds of 1-4. Compounds 1-4 have been prepared in H2O/ethanol mixed-solvent systems with different organic anion co-ligands (NCS-, NO3 -, ox2-). Though the ligand L contains seven N atoms, only four N atoms of triazole rings can participate in coordination and the steric effect prevents other N atoms of L from metal coordination. Because both N1 and N2 in the triazole ring can coordinate with metal ions, there are three bidentate coordination modes, as shown in Scheme . 1 contains modes a and b, whereas 2 and 3 have only mode b and c, respectively. The different coordination modes draw the self-assembly of coordination polymers to form 1D or 2D metal-organic frameworks. It is noted that the angles between benzene and triazole rings are flexible. The various coordination modes together with the flexible dihedral angles make the fact that we could not succeed to anticipate the self-assembly results of L and metal ions. In compounds 1-3, L adopts bidentate bridging mode, whereas thiocyanate or nitrate ligands adopt a monodentate N-coordination mode; in 4, L adopts only the terminal monodentate mode, which may be ascribed to the different coordination abilities for ligand and anion co-ligands. The coordination ability of L is stronger than that of thiocyanate or nitrate anions but weaker than that of oxalate anion ligands.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="cg070208xh00001" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<graphic xlink:href="cg-2007-00208x_0002.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of 1 contains two kinds of crystallographic independent zinc(II) centers, six-coordinate Zn1 and four-coordinate Zn2. Additionally, two lattice aqua molecules and one disorder methanol molecule also exist in the asymmetric unit of 1. To the best of our knowledge, in the previous triazole−zinc(II) systems, four- and six-coordinated zinc(II) compounds have been separately reported; however, those compounds simultaneously four- and six-coordinated Zn(II) centers are never reported. Compound 1 represents the first triazole−zinc(II) compounds simultaneously comprising four- and six-coordinated zinc(II) centers.
elements.clean_text: As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of 1 contains two kinds of crystallographic independent zinc(II) centers, six-coordinate Zn1 and four-coordinate Zn2. Additionally, two lattice aqua molecules and one disorder methanol molecule also exist in the asymmetric unit of 1. To the best of our knowledge, in the previous triazole-zinc(II) systems, four- and six-coordinated zinc(II) compounds have been separately reported; however, those compounds simultaneously four- and six-coordinated Zn(II) centers are never reported. Compound 1 represents the first triazole-zinc(II) compounds simultaneously comprising four- and six-coordinated zinc(II) centers.

elements.content: (a) Structural unit of1 showing two kinds of crystallographic independent zinc(II) centers; (b) 1D doubled-stranded chain structure of 1 and terminal Zn(NCS)3 structural unit.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Structural unit of1 showing two kinds of crystallographic independent zinc(II) centers; (b) 1D doubled-stranded chain structure of 1 and terminal Zn(NCS)3 structural unit.

elements.content: In 1, Zn1 is six-coordinated to six nitrogen atoms from six L molecules, forming a slightly distorted octahedral geometry. Zn2 is four-coordinated to three nitrogen atoms of three terminal thiocyanate ligands and one nitrogen atom from one L molecule, forming a tetrahedral coordination geometry. Zn1 is linked by four bridging L molecules to form a 1D double-strand chain, whereas each Zn2 center gathers three thiocyanate ligands to form terminal dangling Zn(NCS)3 structural unit (Figure b). Furthermore, the dangling Zn(NCS)3 structural unit acting as a branch links the Zn1 center via one bridging ligand, extending the 1D double-strand chain along the crystallographic c-axis. The nearest Zn1···Zn1 distances are 10.834 Å, whereas the nearest Zn1···Zn2 distances are longer (12.898 Å). Notably, two triazole rings of those ligands between Zn1 centers have dihedral angle of 46.9°, which is much larger than that between Zn1 and Zn2 centers (8.0°). The result also reveals that two triazole groups of L are somewhat flexible and rotational around pyridine group moieties in order to meet the geometrical preference of metal centers.
elements.clean_text: In 1, Zn1 is six-coordinated to six nitrogen atoms from six L molecules, forming a slightly distorted octahedral geometry. Zn2 is four-coordinated to three nitrogen atoms of three terminal thiocyanate ligands and one nitrogen atom from one L molecule, forming a tetrahedral coordination geometry. Zn1 is linked by four bridging L molecules to form a 1D double-strand chain, whereas each Zn2 center gathers three thiocyanate ligands to form terminal dangling Zn(NCS)3 structural unit (Figure b). Furthermore, the dangling Zn(NCS)3 structural unit acting as a branch links the Zn1 center via one bridging ligand, extending the 1D double-strand chain along the crystallographic c-axis. The nearest Zn1⋅⋅⋅Zn1 distances are 10.834 Å, whereas the nearest Zn1⋅⋅⋅Zn2 distances are longer (12.898 Å). Notably, two triazole rings of those ligands between Zn1 centers have dihedral angle of 46.9°, which is much larger than that between Zn1 and Zn2 centers (8.0°). The result also reveals that two triazole groups of L are somewhat flexible and rotational around pyridine group moieties in order to meet the geometrical preference of metal centers.

elements.content: For 1, these 1D chains are stacked along the crystallographic b-axis. As shown in Figure , two sets of non-classical hydrogen bonds (C−H···N and C−H···S hydrogen bonds) cannot be neglected because of the absence of other obvious strong interactions between these 1D chains in 1. These weak interactions link these 1D chains into a 3D supramolecular architecture (C13−H13···N2, 3.325 Å; C17−H17···N9, 3.067 Å; C15−H15···S2, 3.713 Å). Similar examples about these weak interactions can also be observed in the previous literature. Guest lattice water molecules and disordered methanol molecules are encapsulated in channels.
elements.clean_text: For 1, these 1D chains are stacked along the crystallographic b-axis. As shown in Figure , two sets of non-classical hydrogen bonds (C-H⋅⋅⋅N and C-H⋅⋅⋅S hydrogen bonds) cannot be neglected because of the absence of other obvious strong interactions between these 1D chains in 1. These weak interactions link these 1D chains into a 3D supramolecular architecture (C13-H13⋅⋅⋅N2, 3.325 Å; C17-H17⋅⋅⋅N9, 3.067 Å; C15-H15⋅⋅⋅S2, 3.713 Å). Similar examples about these weak  interactions can also be observed in the previous literature. Guest lattice water molecules and disordered methanol molecules are encapsulated in channels.

elements.content: Three-dimensional supramolecular architecture of1 containing 1D hydrophobic and hydrophilic channels.
elements.clean_text: 2  Three-dimensional supramolecular architecture of1 containing 1D hydrophobic and hydrophilic channels.

elements.content: (a) One-dimensional doubled-stranded chain structure of2; (b) 3D hydrogen-bonding architecture of 2.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) One-dimensional doubled-stranded chain structure of2; (b) 3D hydrogen-bonding architecture of 2.

elements.content: When Zn(NCS)2 is replaced by Cd(NCS)2 in the above reaction system, 2 was obtained. For 2, there is only one crystallographic six-coordinate Cd(II) center, six-coordinated by four triazole nitrogen atoms of L ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two terminal thiocyanate ligands. Two triazole rings of L have a dihedral angle of 21.6° and neighboring Cd···Cd distances bridged by L are 10.993 Å. L adopts bridging bidentate modes linking Cd(II) centers to extend into 1D double-stranded chain structure. Similar to that of 1, weak C−H···N and C−H···S interactions can be found in 2 (Figure ). For 1 and 2, the structural motif variation may be a result of the different coordination features of metal ions, because in the starting materials, Zn(NCS)2 was replaced by Cd(NCS)2.
elements.clean_text: When Zn(NCS)2 is replaced by Cd(NCS)2 in the above reaction system, 2 was obtained. For 2, there is only one crystallographic six-coordinate Cd(II) center, six-coordinated by four triazole nitrogen atoms of L ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two terminal thiocyanate ligands. Two triazole rings of L have a dihedral angle of 21.6° and neighboring Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd distances bridged by L are 10.993 Å. L adopts  bridging bidentate modes linking Cd(II) centers to extend into 1D double-stranded chain structure. Similar to that of 1, weak C-H⋅⋅⋅N and C-H⋅⋅⋅S interactions can be found in 2 (Figure ). For 1 and 2, the structural motif variation may be a result of the different coordination features of metal ions, because in the starting materials, Zn(NCS)2 was replaced by Cd(NCS)2.

elements.content: Compound 3 crystallizes in the orthorhombic crystal system with the P212121 chiral space group. As shown in Figure , an asymmetric unit of 3 contains one six-coordinate Cd(II) center, two L ligands, and two monodentate nitrate anions. Each Cd(II) center is in an octahedral geometry and links four neighboring Cd(II) centers via four bridging L molecules, forming a 2D sheet structure along the crystallographic ac plane. The dihedral angles of two triazole rings of L ligands are 5.5 and 7.4°, respectively.
elements.clean_text: Compound 3 crystallizes in the orthorhombic crystal system with the P212121 chiral space group. As shown in Figure , an asymmetric unit of 3 contains one six-coordinate Cd(II) center, two L ligands, and two monodentate nitrate anions. Each Cd(II) center is in an octahedral geometry and links four neighboring Cd(II) centers via four bridging L molecules, forming a 2D sheet structure along the crystallographic ac plane. The dihedral angles of two triazole rings of L ligands are 5.5 and 7.4°, respectively.

elements.content: Structural units of3 showing that the four ligand molecules coordinated to Cd(II) centers are arranged different from those of 2.
elements.clean_text: 4  Structural units of3 showing that the four ligand molecules coordinated to Cd(II) centers are arranged different from those of 2.

elements.content: (a) Two kinds of 1D helical structure are interlinked to form 2D planes. (b) Side view of 2D bilayer planes.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Two kinds of 1D helical structure are interlinked to form 2D planes. (b) Side view of 2D bilayer planes.

elements.content: Upon further careful investigation of the structure of 3, it can be seen that two kinds of 1D helical structure are interlinked via Cd(II) centers as hingers to form 2D planes (Figure a). The two kinds of helical structure have the same spiral length of 12.44 Å, whereas one has a spiral width of 7.26 Å and the other has a spiral width of 7.21 Å. Because of the existence of the helical structure, a side view of the 2D plane bilayer structure of 3 can be found (Figure b).
elements.clean_text: Upon further careful investigation of the structure of 3, it can be seen that two kinds of 1D helical structure are interlinked via Cd(II) centers as hingers to form 2D planes (Figure a). The two kinds of helical structure have the same spiral length of 12.44 Å, whereas one has a spiral width of 7.26 Å and the other has a spiral width of 7.21 Å. Because of the existence of the helical structure, a side view of the 2D plane bilayer structure of 3 can be found (Figure b).

elements.content: In 2 and 3, the anions NCS- and NO3 - occupy only the axial site of six-coordinate Cd(II) centers and act as terminal ligands. Cd(II) centers are both extended via four bidentate ligands into 1D (2) or 2D (3) frameworks because the four ligands coordinated to Cd(II) centers are arranged in different manners. The result also represents a novel example tuning the framework structure on the basis of CdL2(X)2 structural units (X = NCS- or NO3 -) from 1D to 2D via anion variation.
elements.clean_text: In 2 and 3, the anions NCS- and NO3 - occupy only the axial site of six-coordinate Cd(II) centers and act as terminal ligands. Cd(II) centers are both extended via four bidentate ligands into 1D (2) or 2D (3) frameworks because the four ligands coordinated to Cd(II) centers are arranged in different manners. The result also represents a novel example tuning the framework structure on the basis of CdL2(X)2 structural units (X = NCS- or NO3 -) from 1D to 2D via anion variation.

elements.content: For 4, its asymmetric unit contains one Cd(II) center, one oxalate bridge, one L molecule, one coordinated water molecule, and two lattice aqua molecules. The Cd(II) center is six-coordinated by four oxygen atoms from two bis(bidentate) oxalate bridges, one nitrogen atom from monodentate triazole ligand, and one coordinate water molecule. Each Cd(II) center links two neighboring Cd(II) centers via bis(bidentate) oxalate bridges forming a 1D zigzag chain structure (Figure ). As for the supramolecular architecture of 4, strong O−H···O hydrogen bonds exist between the 1D chain and lattice water molecules, which extend these 1D chains into a 2D supramolecular sheet (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: For 4, its asymmetric unit contains one Cd(II) center, one oxalate bridge, one L molecule, one coordinated water molecule, and two lattice aqua molecules. The Cd(II) center is six-coordinated by four oxygen atoms from two bis(bidentate) oxalate bridges, one nitrogen atom from monodentate triazole ligand, and one coordinate water molecule. Each Cd(II) center links two neighboring Cd(II) centers via bis(bidentate) oxalate bridges forming a 1D zigzag chain structure (Figure ). As for the supramolecular architecture of 4, strong O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds exist between the 1D chain and lattice water molecules, which extend these 1D chains into a 2D supramolecular sheet (Figure ).

elements.content: Two-dimensional hydrogen net in4 formed via O−H···O hydrogen synthons (ligand molecules and hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity).
elements.clean_text: 7  Two-dimensional hydrogen net in4 formed via O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen synthons (ligand molecules and hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity).

elements.content: As shown in Figure , solid-state fluorescence spectra of L and 1−4 at room temperature has been determined. The free ligand L has weak fluorescence emission bands centered at ca. 340 cm-1. In comparison with that of the free ligand, 1−3 show similar strong emission bands centered at 342 (1), 340 (2), and 339 (3) cm-1, respectively, which should be ascribed to intraligand fluorescence emissions. The effective enhancement of emission bands in 1−3 should be due to the coordination of L to Cd center increasing the ligand conformational rigidity, thereby reducing the nonradiative decay of the intraligand (π−π*) excited state. However, for 4, the relatively wide emission bands are red-shifted to around 377 cm-1 (λex = 320 nm). Because no emission bands for L and ox ligands can be observed in the region of 360−400 cm-1, the fluorescence band of 4 can be ascribed to charge transfer between metal Cd(II) centers and ligands.
elements.clean_text: As shown in Figure , solid-state fluorescence spectra of L and 1-4 at room temperature has been determined. The free ligand L has weak fluorescence emission bands centered at ca. 340 cm-1. In comparison with that of the free ligand, 1-3 show similar strong emission bands centered at 342 (1), 340 (2), and 339 (3) cm-1, respectively, which should be ascribed to intraligand fluorescence emissions. The effective enhancement of emission bands in 1-3 should be due to the coordination of L to Cd center increasing the ligand conformational rigidity, thereby reducing the nonradiative decay of the intraligand  (π-π*) excited state. However, for 4, the relatively wide emission bands are red-shifted to around 377 cm-1 (λex = 320 nm). Because no emission bands for L and ox ligands can be observed in the region of 360-400 cm-1, the fluorescence band of 4 can be ascribed to charge transfer between metal Cd(II) centers and ligands.

elements.content: Solid-state fluorescence spectra of1−4 and ligand molecules.
elements.clean_text: 8  Solid-state fluorescence spectra of1-4 and ligand molecules.

elements.content: In conclusion, using various anions in the synthesized systems of L and metal ions, we isolated four novel coordination polymers with four kinds of coordination topologies. 1 is a 1D double-bridged chain constructed by six-coordinate Zn(II) ions with four-coordinated Zn(II) ions as branchs. SCN- and NO3 - anions could tune the structures from 1D to 2D coordination polymers for 2 and 3, respectively. 4 is a 1D zigzag chain linked by oxalate anions. The variation of structural motifs of 1−4 indicates anion co-ligands, and metal-directing strategies have a profound effect on the construction of novel functional frameworks. All compounds exhibit strong luminescence properties at room temperature. The varying coordination modes of L and the preparation of 3 with chiral crystals also indicate L has great potential for synthesizing novel frameworks with intriguing structure and unique properties. The important and potentially attractive aspect of this contribution is the fact that the L being used is luminescent, thereby giving potential functionality (such as small molecule sensing by fluorescence quenching) to these metal−organic frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
4. Conclusion

In conclusion, using various anions in the synthesized systems of L and metal ions, we isolated four novel coordination polymers with four kinds of coordination topologies. 1 is a 1D double-bridged chain constructed by six-coordinate Zn(II) ions with four-coordinated Zn(II) ions as branchs. SCN- and NO3 - anions could tune the structures from 1D to 2D coordination polymers for 2 and 3, respectively. 4 is a 1D zigzag chain linked by oxalate anions. The variation of structural motifs of 1-4 indicates anion co-ligands, and metal-directing strategies have a profound effect on the construction of novel functional frameworks. All compounds exhibit strong luminescence properties at room temperature. The varying coordination modes of L and the preparation of 3 with chiral crystals also indicate L has great potential for synthesizing novel frameworks with intriguing structure and unique properties. The important and potentially attractive aspect of this contribution is the fact that the L being used is luminescent, thereby giving potential functionality (such as small molecule sensing by fluorescence quenching) to these metal-organic frameworks.

cln_elements.content:
Synthesis of {[Zn 3 L 4 (NCS) 6 ]·2CH 3 OH·H 2 O} n (1). A solution of L (10.8 mg, 0.05 mmol) in a 1:1 mixture of methanol and H2O (20 mL) was added to a solution of Zn(NCS)2 (9.0 mg, 0.05 mmol) in H2O (10 mL). The resulting solution was refluxed with stirring for ca. 3 h and then filtrated to stand for several days at room temperature. Colorless crystals were obtained in 31% yield based on Zn(II) salts. Anal. Calcd. for C22H19N17O1.5S3Zn1.5 (1):  C, 35.72; H, 2.59; N, 32.19. Found:  C, 35.85; H, 2.65; N, 32.45. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3429 (s), 3370 (m), 2075 (s), 1640 (s), 1523 (m), 1412 (s), 1254 (m), 1176 (m), 1020 (m), 870 (m), 762 (w), 617 (w), 529 (w).

Synthesis of [CdL 2 (NCS) 2 ] n (2). 2 was synthesized by the methods similar to those used for 1. Yield, 51% (based on Cd(II) salts). Anal. Calcd. for C20H14CdN16S2 (2):  C, 36.68; H, 2.16; N, 34.22. Found:  C, 36.81; H, 2.23; N, 34.38. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3158 (w), 2071 (s), 1656 (w), 1513 (s), 1406 (m), 1234 (s), 1149 (w), 1093 (m), 1038 (s), 975 (w), 886 (m), 767 (s), 664 (m), 518 (m).

Synthesis of [CdL 2 (NO 3 ) 2 ] n (3). 3 was synthesized by methods similar to those used for 1. Yield, 43% (based on Cd(II) salts). Anal. Calcd. for C18H14CdN16O6 (3):  C, 32.62; H, 2.13; N, 33.81. Found:  C, 32.74; H, 2.28; N, 33.93. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3120 (w), 1615 (s), 1375 (vs), 1530 (w), 1481 (w), 1307 (vs), 1215 (m), 864 (s), 765 (w), 674 (m), 520 (m).

Synthesis of {[CdL( μ -ox)(H 2 O)]·2H 2 O} n (4). 4 was synthesized by methods similar to those used for 1. Yield, 46% (based on Cd(II) salts). Anal. Calcd. for C11H13CdN7O7 (4):  C, 28.25; H, 2.80; N, 20.97. Found:  C, 28.13; H, 2.71; N, 20.81. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3454 (m), 3425 (s), 1608 (vs), 1362 (m), 1311 (vs), 906 (m), 871 (m), 763 (m), 671 (m), 525 (m).
